Comment: That's two airlines I wont fly now; United and Delta. The CEO of the company is absolutely wrong for not taking responsibility. Sure they were legally correct, but they were wrong in every other way for a number of reasons. First of all, they should not have boarded everyone if they new they were "overbooked" (this is a whole different issue). The problem could have and should have been resolved with no one on the plane. Had they done that in the first place, the incident never would have happened. As for the "overbooking", they need to be a lot clearer on what they mean. Did the four United employees need to get to a destination that was short staffed for a flight, or were they just going home? If it was critical that these employees get on the flight, and they asked their customers before getting on the plane, I am pretty sure they would have gotten volunteers. They also didn't offer the maximum that they are allowed to offer. Instead, they chose to impose their will.

Comment: Comments on the Civic sedan...

I bought the 2016 Touring model (turbo). It handles really well and the engine is pretty perky. It is roomy and very comfortable even after a few hours of driving - no back pain. I'm tall, so although Mazda would have been interesting, there was not enough headroom in either the 3 or the 6. 

My only complaint with the Civic has been the electronics. The infotainment system was in 4 times before they finally fixed it with a new unit. Now the thermostat won't shut down when it's hit its heat threshold. One visit to the dealer and still not fixed, so yet another is needed. I never had so many issues with my previous Toyotas, but I never enjoyed driving those cars as much as the Civic. I think it's mostly the car (teething pains on a  brand new model) but all these visits could be the dealer's incompetence...or maybe he likes warranty work?  

Has any other 2016-17 Civic owner had these issues? Did your dealer fix them faster than mine?

Comment: Unfortunately, there is no obvious way to exactly determine what effect the Russian leaking of emails had on the actual results, although with Trump winning Pennsylvania, Michigan and Wisconsin (with a total of 46 Electoral College votes) in each case by 0.7% or less, it would have taken only a small effect to make Clinton the winner. However, there is far stronger evidence that James Comey's issuing a letter  less than three weeks before the election that he was reopening the investigation into Clinton's emails (without any knowledge of whether there was any new, relevant, evidence) had a decisive effect. Before the letter, the consensus of major opinion polls was that Clinton had a 6-6.5% lead in the popular vote but after the letter, in the lead up to the election, this edge dropped to 2-2.5%. Since the final result showed that Clinton had a 2.1% lead in the popular vote, the polls appear to have been quite accurate and that Comey's intervention swung the election to Trump.

Comment: Who gives a crap where the word originated. I spoke about definition, not etymology. 

It's utterly irrelevant where it originated or what it meant when it was created. What matters is what it means today, what people understand when they hear it. Not what it meant once upon a time.

The word "proves"used to mean "to test and show to be false", giving English the expression "the exception that proves the rule" - which literally meant "the exception that shows the rule isn't actually a rule and is not really true".

Over time "proves" lost the meaning of "to show the falsehood of" and only the meaning of "to show it's true" remained, and the proverb survives even though it's modern day meaning makes no sense. It's a kind of bizarre claim that the the rule is true BECAUSE there are exceptions to it.

Words change their meanings over time - and if you don't know the current meaning, you cannot communicate honestly, logically or usefully.

Comment: I appreciate the role of precedents but seizing on the Arar case as justification for the Khadr settlement ignores salient differences between the two. Canada's responsibility for Arar's rendition and torture was not secondary. His detention was predicated on a false RCMP report branding him a terrorist - a claim later proved baseless. His treatment was harsher than that of Khadr, his economic damages were higher, and the harm to his family greater. Unlike Arar, Khadr bears some responsibility for his predicament as does his family.

But quantum is not the key here; nor is it any disingenuous notion of government cutting its losses to protect the taxpayer. Allowing litigation to reach its natural conclusion in this instance is arguably better 'public policy' than imposing a settlement supported by fewer than one in three Canadians. Nor would it constitute 'very bad law' which, as I'm sure you understand, is rarely served better in the bank rooms of cabinet than in an open court of law.

Comment: In reading some of the comments , it appears that many people do not have a clear idea of the role of the official Opposition. They are the voice of the people who have questions about government actions. Obviously everything that the government is not wrong or open to interpretation, but some things are. There is also the Opposition's particular stance on certain issues to be considered. If for instance as has happened government approves pipelines, they will get Opposition support. In the case of Khadr the Conservatives have been very clear, as have a great many Canadians who don't vote Conservative that they object to the large payment. They don't object to the Charter, they are not anti-law, but perhaps anti large settlement. It is not the role of the Liberals to tell the Conservatives what they can an can not object to. The money is gone and is not coming back, so this is a matter of principle here. If this story has legs it will come up in 2019, hard to keep it going until then.

Comment: Having worked for a major Canadian corporation we ran into two key roadblocks with the patent process:

1) the cost and complexity of filing a patent in Canada, then with USPTO was huge. Since we were not really in that business, we we unlikely to really profit from the patent, except to say we had developed a terrific  and unique idea. Eventually we decided not to pursue additional patents even though many of the things we did on our web tools were firsts, and useful.

2) USPTO allowed ideas to be patented. We were served several times with claims for patents that were simply PowerPoint ideas submitted and then granted patents. They had never had an implementation, they were overly broad, and they allowed owners to sue for big numbers with the onus of proving prior art on us (which also cost money). 

So I fully agree that NAFTA 2.0 should contain a reset of patent process, allowing a patent in one country to be recognized by all, and to restrict to "real" inventions.

Comment: Where does all the money go that is given by taxpayers to indigineous communities? The only reports provided by the mainstream media focus on alleged under funding in certain areas.  But if examined on the basis of total funding per capita to indigineous communities, aboriginal communities  receive far, far more than is provided to non-aboriginals.  For example, Nunavut (created to be a model of aboriginal self-government) receives per capita annual funding from the federal taxpayers of $42,055  (yes, that's right, a family of four in Nunavut receives annual support of $168,000 from federal taxpayers). That compares to the per-capita funding from the federal government for all Canadians of $1,986.  Federal funding for Nunavut per capita is over 20 times greater than the average for all Canadians.  How meaningful, then, would any claim be that Nunavut is underfunded in one given area of government services?

Source: http://www.fin.gc.ca/fedprov/mtp-eng.asp

Comment: Lower tax rates on dividends reflect the fact that corporate tax has already been paid on income distributed as dividends.  Taxing the same income twice produces unhealthy economic incentives, and the lower tax rate on dividends only partly compensates for that.  

Lower tax rates on capital gains reflect the fact that much of what is taxed as "gain" is actually inflationary price increase, and does not reflect a true gain in value.  Taxing inflationary price increases gives the government an incentive to debase the currency in order to confiscate more assets from taxpayers than they can afford to pay.  

Unless we want a country where tax evasion is the number one pre-occupation, as it is in many parts of the world, better for the government to think twice before disturbing the integrity of the business income tax system.

Comment: Theft by deception from the Navy Exchange is a federal crime and should be investigated by the FBI because the alleged perp is a civilian.  NCIS can investigate, but they cannot prosecute unless the subject is a military person or dependent thereof.  Le also possessed stolen identification and stolen credit cards, apparently belonging to a military person or family member, which he used to gain access to the NEX and purchase the items.  It would be appropriate for HPD to investigate the theft of the ID and credit cards if it occurred off base, but not for crimes committed on Federal property.   However, when a crime involves federal and local jurisdictions, one or the other can waive jurisdiction to allow the other to investigate and prosecute the case.  Since the most serious crimes occurred on federal property, I do not believe the FBI would waive jurisdiction and turn the entire case over to HPD.  I think there is more to this case than contained in the story.

Comment: A poem isn't immigration policy.  Even when it was written there were laws that didn't let in all the "wretched refuse".  Not if they were Chinese, not if they had various diseases.  While I agree with those who think the proposed policy is too restrictive and possibly elitist, I would not agree with a policy that let every poor wretched soul on earth immigrate without limits to the US because someone wrote a sentimental poem 100 years ago and we mustn't tamper with the rules laid down by that poem.  It wouldn't be good for the country and it they would find a country just as wretched as what they left.  

We need to move away from the chain migration system that has evolved, and pay more attention to protecting opportunities for Americans and legal immigrants.  The proposal needs work, and it will be modified many times before (if ever) it becomes law.  But the guidelines need to be what is best for the country (residents already here), not trying to follow the letter of a poem.

Comment: The article states without reference that "Certain foods cause adverse effects in about one in 13 Canadians."  That's about 8% of the population: a big statement but where do the figures come from and what do they mean?  Would sniffing pepper and sneezing be an adverse effect? 

According to the Wikipedia entry on Food intolerance, not the most scientific source but it carries citations for its sources: "Estimates of the prevalence of food intolerance vary widely from 2% to over 20% of the population. So far only three prevalence studies in Dutch and English adults have been based on double-blind, placebo-controlled food challenges. The reported prevalences of food allergy/intolerance (by questionnaires) were 12% to 19%, whereas the confirmed prevalences varied from 0.8% to 2.4%. For intolerance to food additives the prevalence varied between 0.01 and 0.23%."

Comment: No and yes.
I think the measure around passive income closes a loophole in which corporations are used primarily to shelter investment income.  The higher taxes are only on the investment income.  If you're saving money in a savings account a few months a year and taking it out of the savings account to pay your staff during slow periods, you're not going to be paying a lot of tax on the interest you're earning, and you can get around this by using a line of credit and deducting the interest payments your company pays instead of paying tax on the income your company earns.  You can even personally loan your company the money and have it pay you the interest.

Comment: There no easy way to find out if there was a phantom distribution based on your T3 info.  If the money is from a distribution, it does not have to be declared on your T3 as you are not paying tax on it, and there's no box on the form on which to declare it..  On the flip side I have had Capital gains get reinvested in the fund - that was declared on my T3, I paid tax on it, and now it is part of the ACB for my shares.   I only discovered this when I got my T3 info for the year and found no corresponding payout to the capital gain in my records.

Jesus was not a macho tough guy taking nails for God; he was a man who led a political movement against the established religion that favored the rich and powerful and got killed because of it. Christ's service was to afflict the comfortable and to comfort the afflicted. Not so, Pete Kelly. 

Thank you, Shannyn.

Comment: Good question Walter. I was also wondering about the double dipping.

These 'fund of funds' often have two layers of fees. One paid for the management of the base fund and another layer on top to pay for 'wrapping' the funds together. Would be good to know the total take on funds.

If double dipping, it would be much more efficient to build your own fund of funds (or ETF/fund/stock).  It takes time, attention and you have to have an interest in doing the management. But giving up this much fees will dramatically eat into your retirement nest egg.

Comment: I don't disagree with anything in this article about what is needed (use of cleaner "transition fuels", use of nuclear power, and a moonshot effort on feasible clean power and carbon capture), but I think it very naive to suggest that Trump may help things along.  So far (and all we have to go by as a guide right now is what he has said and done to date) there is no indication that he will help, and he's even given signs that he won't.

The move towards cleaner fuels and to some extent technological change will happen without him.  The problem is that nuclear power expansion and a "moonshot" or "Manhattan Project" scale effort cannot occur without the moral and financial support of governments.  This is what is needed, and the signs don't suggest that Trump is interested or even sees a need to do this.

Comment: "I recall in the Sixties ..."  which means, Andrew, you probably remember a time when "women professionals" was an oxymoron.  Me, too...and I distinctly recall the first female announcer and first female newscaster hired by the station in the mid-1970s.   See?  Definite progress, no?

Broadcasting? A profession? "Not the same," doctors, dentists and lawyers might sniff.  Well, many of us did consider it so.  An 8-hour day?  Maybe the morning show guy (who got up at 4:45 to be on the air at 6.) Even he did Saturday remotes.  After a five-day week, I'd roll in for 3-4 hours on a Saturday morning, too, to learn more about my craft from a Vancouver writer who came in part-time.  Man, did I learn.  No extra dough, either.  Just...priceless lessons.  Stayed until 6:30 many nights. The production studios were empty and I could record, edit, play around, discover what was possible... 

Maybe there was one difference from, say, the legal firm.  I had FUN, every single damn day.

Comment: I think Sinnott's findings hold up. We all know bears and other wildlife will use trails to travel, especially when they're relatively empty most of the time. Cyclists are more likely to approach at a higher speed, and perhaps more quietly than a hiker, giving the bear and the cyclist less reaction time to deal with the other's sudden presence.

That said, it's a risk we all take when we go out here in Alaska. Even in town in parks like Kincaid or Far North Bicentennial Park (FNBP), we know there are animals out there, and some of those are bear. Taking basic precautions like knowing the trails, listening to other riders about who's seen bear tracks, scat etc where, and carrying bear spray.

I rode FNBP for years with my father, an avid cyclist. He talked with other riders and knew when to avoid certain trails like Rover's Run. I never encountered a bear riding, but we had spray if we needed it. Basic precautions like Sinnott says DO WORK.

Comment: Before everyone gets upset about this news, the amount of lumber the US gets from Russia basically went from "nothing" to "next to nothing".

In 2015 the US imported about $18B worth of lumber from Canada and only $195M from Russia (source: http://wits.worldbank.org/CountryProfile/en/Country/USA/Year/2015/TradeFlow/Import/Partner/All/Product/44-49_Wood).

 So even though that 40% number looks big, scary and scandalous, we're talking about a very small actual increase in total imports. Is it still scandalous? Sure. But it's not like this is a massive reshaping of the wood industry here.

Comment: Before the pro-gun rights advocates start to hijack this thread--spewing their "guns don't kill people" rhetoric, I thought I'd mention that Nevada, despite being a top tourist destination, the  gun laws in this state are some of the most lax in the entire nation. For example, nearly anyone can purchase a gun without an owner license or firearm registration. What this means is that even criminals and those with a history of mental illness are allowed to buy as many guns as they want. On top of that, gun dealers in Nevada aren't required to have a license either nor does the state of Nevada regulate any transactions and sales from gun shops who operate in this state. What this means is that virtually anyone can purchase as many guns as they can afford because there are no laws regulating the quantity of guns being sold. While a permit is required for concealed carry, none is required to carry a conspicuous gun, which could include assault weapons which are also legal.

Comment: You're right guys, I think I multiplied the five employees twice in my calculation.

Let's take, suedaninvestments example,

$33,000 per year more in wages for five full-time employees.  Let's assume wages will eventually have to go up by 25% over the next 2-3 years to hit $15.  That means current labour costs are $132,000 ($33000/0.25)
If labour costs are currently running at 10% -12% of revenue, that is say $1,300,000 of revenues per employee.  Wage increase of $33,000/$1,300,000 means my revenue has to go up by 2.5% to cover the extra cost. 

For restaurants, that top line revenue number will have to go up by around 7%. 

However, point to be made is that everyone's cost goes up, not just yours.  If you are running a good business, you can justify that price increase because everyone will be in that boat and will have to do the same.  If you have to eat that yourself as an owner, you don't have a feasible business, sorry.

Comment: The proposed amendment to the foreign buyer tax regime is appropriate but the basic problems remain.

First, it is actually very easy to circumvent the tax.  A numbered company with one's BC resident lawyer the named representative (and you with the hidden beneficial interest) will do the trick and this is only one of many dodges available.

Second, the tax is a one time cost at the time of purchase and does nothing to prevent the property remaining vacant or to generate any surtax thereafter.

Third, it is open to challenge under NAFTA and other international free trade agreements to which Canada is a Party.

The BC Liberals have over the past couple of years been largely motivated by the partisan political need to appear to be on top of the residential real estate issue as that issue has evolved.  Their response at each turn has been piecemeal and ad hoc.  More to the point, it has beed inadequate and without clear purpose.

Comment: Roundabouts reduce severe collisions but result in a larger frequency of minor collisions. Every once in a while, someone attempts to use the center of the roundabout as a launch ramp. This, too, typically ends poorly.

Comment: Libraries do not have a constitutional obligation to supply free pornography.  The First Amendment states: Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof; or abridging the freedom of speech, or of the press; or the right of the people peaceably to assemble, and to petition the government for a redress of grievances. Here, the library, part  of the State isn't prohibiting  porn in an individual's private life, it just will not provide the free wifi.  For example, the State cannot prohibit all strip joints; it can zone where strip joints are located due to secondary effects.  Similar to strip joints; liquor stores;bars the State has a interest in zoning where these are located. By analogy,  the State doesn't have to supply  strippers or alcohol or free porn. People need to pay for their own porn. Last,  porn sites have under age victims of human trafficking, unlike a racy book where no crime is involved.

Comment: GDP means little about the population - what you need to look at to correlate quality is GDP per capita (how individuals are doing in the economy) and GDP per capita is in decline and has been since immigration levels started to increase drastically in the 90's. This is connected with the critical levels of debt which is the only way that there is still a middle class in Canada. 

What that means is that the economy grows a little, population has grown a lot via immigration levels, so everyone does worse even though there has been growth. It is classic economics in that it shows diminishing margin of returns on immigration levels meaning that the levels are far beyond what they should be. Works for business and banks (more consumers, more debt serfs, downward pressure on wages and human rights due to increasing competition) and is terribly destructive to middle and lower economic classes which includes recent immigrants. The answer: lower immigration levels or pro-slow immigration.

Comment: Some in both the US and Canada want to negotiate a new US-Canada free trade deal apart from Mexico. This would entail several awkward factors:

1. In its current frame of mind, the US would make would make many demands that Canadians would find unpalatable and would reject many that Canadians consider important, including several currently imbedded under NAFTA. 

2. There would be strong US lobbies to simply cancel NAFTA unless all US demands were met.  In response, Canada would have to be prepared to bargain hard and long (including being prepared to reject a new agreement if the terms were too unfavorable).

3. A protracted period of anxiety and uncertainty would exist pending the final outcome of such negotiations.

4. In short, Canada currently is deeply intertwined economically with both the US and Mexico and we would be at a disadvantage negotiating a new treaty  at this time from scratch.

I would be fine with the previous $2-3 million caps, indexed to inflation, with a high risk fund picking up the amounts over those caps.

Raising prices astronomically on a product that has been out for years, and particularly when the current producer didn't even develop it, is morally wrong, and if pharmaceutical companies aren't going to do the right thing, there needs to, unfortunately, be government regulation that is used when capitalism isn't tempered with morality. But do spare me the spectacle of a Kasich-Hickenlooper ticket.  Just. No.

Comment: At least we can call Joseph Boyden a Canadian, and that's good enough for me. I consider Mr. Boyden one this country's finest writers, and I hope that this invasion of his privacy won't affect his ability to continue writing these remarkable stories.
This whole cultural appropriation debate is nonsense. Writers must be free to imagine and compose their own stories as they see fit. It's strange that nobody has ever criticized William Shakespeare for culturally appropriating stories about Denmark, Scotland and Italy --particularly Rome--all places he never visited in his lifetime. If they had and he stopped writing his plays as a result, we would not have Hamlet, Macbeth, Romeo & Juliet or Julius Caesar today.
My advice to Joseph Boyden: Joe, when you are writing your sentences, don't hold punches. You are a very important writer. Keep it up.

Comment: I have lived through 2 earlier housing "bubbles", neither of which was due to immigrant speculation. Both ended up badly.

In 1990, Toronto property prices were zooming out of sight. My niece was desperate to buy a condo before she could no longer afford one. I strongly advised her to wait - and, sure enough, prices came tumbling down when the "bubble burst".

Similarly, in the early years of this century, prices in Florida zoomed upward (more than tripling) for half a decade. Then, they came crashing down after 2006 and many purchasers lost their properties. 

Is there a case for trying to rein in speculation that threatens to lead to a severe correction? Of course! But, the "cause" might have more to do with artificially low interest rates that result from Bank of Canada policies as well as generous mortgage terms based on inflated market prices. 

IMO, the Bank of Canada and OSFI (our financial regulator) may bear more of the blame than foreign speculation.

Comment: rickschlosser, you raise an interesting point.
Most people think in the present and have a built-in bias that relies on recent memory. Psychologists term this as "short-term memory bias" , that is 'the tendency to think that trends we have observed in the recent past will continue'.

Many business management teams struggle against that 'bias' when formulating their forecasts. Some get it right, some fail. Long-term projects -like oil sands- have always required management teams to look far into the future. They consider trends, probabilities, recent advances in various technologies, etc., etc..

Some investors also reject 'short-term memory bias' and invest in companies that have a very good probability to grow/profit in the long-term !

You're right, the current price of oil has nothing to do with the future profitability of the Fort Hill mine. Global oil demand growth shows no signs of dissipating !

Comment: When the transmission in my 2002 Odyssey failed, I also looked at the Honda HR-V and similar compact utility vehicles.  I wanted a tall vehicle that was easy to get in and out of,  with room for 5 and space for a pair of bikes. I bought a new all-electric 2015 Nissan LEAF, with incentives, for $30K.  It has the same leg, head and cargo room as the HR-V, CX-3, RVR and other small CUVs. But it is much quieter to drive with faster and more responsive acceleration. It can pay for itself out of gas savings!  But it won't work for you if you absolutely require AWD, go off-road or take long trips to your birding site.

Comment: Today saw the September update of the Bank of Canada’s Canadian dollar effective exchange rate index (CERI), and of its monthly series for individual exchange rates. The CERI showed a 2.4% monthly increase, partly due to the September increase in the overnight rate, and a 7.3% increase from June, due also to the July rate increase. The loonie rose against the US greenback by 2.8% in September and against all other major currencies with the exception of the pound sterling, where there was a 0.4% drop. As the impact of this hike works its way through the economy it is bound to dampen consumer price inflation, which was already running much below the BoC’s 2% target rate, at 1.4%, in August. It shows just how delusional is the BoC’s argument that the September rate hike was a necessary preventive action to keep inflation from soaring above the target rate.

Supply and demand are always "mismatched" in competitive markets -- actually, in all markets! Otherwise, there wouldn't be a market!

Comment: The argument against the EC isn't that it gives less populated states more votes (that's not even true). It's that it is a winner takes all system where 50+1 in Michigan counts the same as 70% in California. But this is precisely the reason why the EC is in place, it's critical to a large state like the US with divergent interests. It forces parties to appeal broadly. Otherwise, you could have the Coastal People Party that could run on a platform of pillage Texas and the Mid-west while benefiting a handful of coastal states and they'd form government. It's a check on any region becoming so strong that it would mute the votes of other Americans.

Comment: It changes over time. Once interior partitions go up they rarely come down.

My first post graduation job was in an open area office with ceiling mounted speakers dedicated to "pink noise", in contrast to white noise, to try and drown out speech from the other side of the floor. Staff sick time kept going up and up, until they shut down the "pink noise".

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pink_noise

The last time I was in that building, 37 years later, it had been divided by partitions and was so still that you could hear the ventilation system.

Another building I worked in was built in 1981 with a 4 story atrium and open walls along the edge of the big hole. People would lean over the rail on the top floor and shout down to people walking out the building. The brought a BC Tel guy in after people complained about not being able to hear voices on the telephone. Comment: "Why is the Second Amendment the only amendment that can admit of no restrictions? Maybe I should be able to yell fire in a crowded theater to protect all my rights."

1st of all, you error in thinking that a majority of the gun rights movement think that the 2nd Amendment right is unlimited.  Witness the NRA on machine guns and bump stocks.  Ditto for the NRA support of the current background check system.

Second, have you actually read the landmark Heller (2008) decision and the follow on McDonald (2010) decision?  This is what you will find:

1) Firearms "in common civilian use" are protected.  If the people choose to own a type of firearm in significant numbers, it's protected.  Handguns, the #1 murder weapon, were the subject of this decision.
2) Weapons not in common use, are not protected.
3) In order to be banned, a weapon must be both unusual and dangerous.

Since this ruling, most courts have simply ruled as if it did not exist - but other have used it to expand gun rights

I also don't agree that bicycle issues have become "religious" -- political maybe. But I think the bike related ideas and projects in the Transportation System Plan are very pragmatic, actually. And there are good pedestrian projects too.

The TSP is also, I think, city staff trying to actually implement policy passed by the Council: Climate Recovery Ordinance and Vision Zero. Walking is great, but not the answer alone, and not practical for say a 2 mile trip. But a bike, yeah, easy. This is about more options for more people.

Comment: I understand what everyone is saying but to some degree everyone is right and wrong.  To use the home based analogies that I've read.  Yes we need new revenues, you can't live on nothing alone.  You need income sources.  However, when you are looking for a new source of revenue you don't keep spending like you were at your last job.  You scale down on the extra amenities until you can better afford them.  So basically you keep what's necessary and you dump the rest.  

In this case public safety, education, etc.  Are the necessities (like keeping the lights on at home and paying the rent and buying groceries). But you should scale back the other spending to nil, such as movies out of the house, eating out, shopping at the mall etcetera or in terms of government spending the (railroads the tax credits to oil companies, has pipelines, meat packaging plants etc) 

We need a sustainable budget before we can start finding the revenue to support it.  How can you know how much money you need?

Comment: When it comes to RTD, it's Denver that's heavily subsidized while the suburbs get screwed.  Especially with rail.  The vast majority of light rail rides start and/or end in Denver (usually downtown or DIA).  The suburbs don't even come remotely close to that degree of service, but yet the suburbs pay 77% of the taxes that fund RTD.  The tax really ought to be 2x or 3x bigger in the city of Denver and less in the suburbs.

Who doen't want a walkable neighborhood? The problem is it often conflicts with so many other things people also want, like less crowding, more open space, yards, big houses, quiet neighborhoods, low crime, safe places for their kids to play, etc.

The small town life in a small space works fine when you have 1000 people. But small town life for 3-5 million people requires a helluva lot more space. Which is why suburbs and xburbs exist.

The "order of creation" argument is a fallacy. You can read TOSC papers to know why, especially one written by Angel Rodriguez, the retired BRI director of the GC.

May I suggest that you read both letters to Timothy and make a list of all those things Paul says are wrong in the church at Ephesus.

Comment: There are no signals from Pope Francis that moral doctrines regarding "irregular couples" (contracepting, divorced-remarried or LGBTQ) will be reformed during this papacy. And most definitely not regarding abortion.

In Amoris, for example, he not only changed no moral doctrines but changed no canons or disciplines either!  

Fr Martin, like the Pope, reemphasizes the primacy of the pastoral over the legal & repudiates remnants (not saving!) of legalism, rigorism, judgmentalism & exclusivism, while commending mercy & hospitality!

When those who, like Pope Francis or Fr. Martin, ask "Who am I to judge?" --- they are not even talking about objective states & the question doesn't presuppose any given stance regarding this or that moral reality. Instead, consistent with the Gospel injunction not to judge, the question charitably presupposes another's subjective exculpability.

That said, I believe the Church does need to revisit -not only canons & disciplines, but- moral doctrines.

Comment: In Canada, pressing charges isn't up to the defendant. He could take the assailant to civil court but charging a person with an offense is a complicated process and the decision doesn't even rest with the police. Investigating a crime and recommending a charge is the job of the police as an independent body tasked to protect the public. But ultimately, laying a charge against an offender is the job of Crown counsel. That said, this employee was a complete a-hole and deserved to get fired.

Comment: Mental disability is not treated any differently they only classify the animal differently.  It is called emotional support animal or ESA.  And even international airlines recognize and follow the federal rules regarding these animals for American travelers.  As long as you're flying
From America to your destination and back to America.  

The fact that our local airlines dropped the damn ball is absurd.  As long as you have a letter from a doctor (doesn't matter If your disability is mental or physical) then you have a legal right to your service or ESA animal.  This not only includes flying, transport but living arrangements as well.  Places that don't accept pets must accept a service animal because it is legally not considered a pet.  Don't like the laws? Lobby against them.  But the law is the law.

Comment: Concerning Betta splendens: they are sensitive to BOTH air and water temperature because they breathe atmospheric oxygen through a "labyrinth organ" attached to their gills.  Their natural habitat is low dissolved-oxygen, low pH, tropical habitat in Thailand, Vietnam etc.  If the air around their container is cool (as is usually the case in Alaska), the labyrinth organ gets infected and the Betta usually dies.  pH isn't so important, as captive-bred Bettas have adapted to higher pH.  Keep water temperature at about 75-78 degrees F with a standard aquarium water-heater of a size appropriate to your tank.  More importantly, cover it with glass or plexi-glass (with a very narrow space for air-exchange), which will trap warmer air at the water surface where the fish comes up to breathe (hold a Betta under water long enough it'll drown).

Strong lights, such as T-5, promote good plant growth, as AK water is full of phosphates.  Betta naturally occur in thickly vegetated Mekong Delta swamps.

Comment: If we look at the data, the seams on balls used after the 2015 all-star break are slightly smaller, the coefficient of restitution (basically the bounciness of the ball) is slightly higher, and the circumference is slightly lower. All of these aren't by much, but Ben Lindbergh, a baseball analytics writer, wrote that these changes allow for an additional 1.43 mph of ball speed off of the bat (https://theringer.com/2017-mlb-home-run-spike-juiced-ball-testing-reveal-155cd21108bc). Earlier computer models predicted that the home run increase could come from a spike of 1.5 mph, so it isn't far off. That, combined with higher launch angles could lead to the increase we're seeing. Smaller seams can cause pitchers to put more pressure on the ball with their fingers, leading to more blisters. I can't speak to a "conspiracy" from Rob Manfred and the MLB, but that's evidence that the balls are slightly different. We will need more evidence to determine if it is MLB or a manufacturing difference.

Comment: 1/2
You seem determined to characterize persons you disagree with in way that is intended to offend them, and in ways that don't allow for the variations and distinctions among them. My sense in reading this board, and my experience in the offline world, is that is a strategy that polarizes the argument and that almost guarantees no progress in resolving the issues. It's a strategy, in other words, that so obviously guarantees that abortions will continue unabated and avoids discussions that might lead to policies to reduce them.

Comment: India November, in Canada "equal pay for work of equal value" means  (for example) equal pay for registered nurses and foresters employed by one employer.  It's called pay equity and has been law in Ontario for 30 years, although it only applies to the public sector and private sector employers with 10 or more employees.  Only 5 other provinces have such a law, none west of Manitoba.

So no, we don't have equal pay for work of equal value across Canada.

What we do have is "equal pay for equal work" within one workplace, which means the same work, even though it may have a different job title.  We've had that across Canada for more than 50 years now, but it only does part of the job.

Comment: Indeed buses today may travel at a paltry 4-8 mph because of congestion.
However, traffic flow could be improved by adopting what other cities in the mainland have been doing to accomplish traffic congestion relief - installation of an adaptive signal light system that would control most, if not all traffic lights in downtown Honolulu as well as on arterial streets leading to or away from Honolulu.
In addition, a remodeling of all if not most intersections experiencing heavy volume of traffic in downtown Honolulu and arterial streets into a new intersection design would save lots of travel time. 
Travel time is saved by a new intersection design that enables vehicles to make a left turn simultaneously with other vehicles moving forward. No more stopping for left turns.

Comment: The British used their cannons.  

Here is how I summarized the situation in an article published in the Journal of Pacific History a few years ago.

"In the days following Cook’s death, the English vented their rage with shows of force and violence. They saw themselves at war and referred to kanaka maoli as the enemy. In four days, they killed at least 30 kanaka maoli, twice as many people as they had killed in a decade of exploring the Pacific. They turned the ships’ guns on groups of kanaka maoli on shore, burned down a village, and sent ashore armed parties who fired indiscriminately at kanaka maoli. In their rage, they committed atrocities. After slaying Mahimoa and Nohona‘una‘u and capturing Owe, the Englishmen beheaded the two dead men and shook their severed heads in the face of their bound captive."

You can read all about it in The Journals of Captain James Cook, edited by Beaglehole.

Comment: Those of us who live in neighborhoods that have been overwhelmed by homeless gangs understand that a big part of their existence involves the procurement and use of illegal drugs. They don't get the money for those drugs by stealing the recycleables and redeeming them; they break into our homes and steal our belongings (as well as intimidating any other users of much of the public space they have privatized). Our local homeless population is intertwined intimately with our local drug and crime problems, which are growing rapidly even though national crime rates are down.

(Note: none of that is to say that every homeless person is a drug addict and criminal, just that they are much more likely to be.)

The fact that this crime involved both drugs and a homeless person is certainly useful information where the juxtaposition of crime, drugs and homelessness is topical.

Comment: Clarence Crawford, thanks for your thoughtful reflection.  But there is neither connection nor meaningful historical similarity between the Confederacy and the Third Reich. 

The Confederacy was rooted in an 18th century seigneurial society, agricultural in economy and aristocratic in organization.  Such societies from Moscow to Sicily to Jamaica to New Orleans regarded owning, or controlling, human labor for their land as a foundation stone of human society.  But otherwise, the ethical and religious values of the Confederacy were just those of standard low-church Protestantism. Nazism, on the other hand, is rooted in a confluence of racialism, socialism, and militarism. It would not have existed without an urban proletariat, which the Confederacy lacked.  Nazism disdains all aristocracies and regards the party's monopoly on force as the only ethical and legal arbiter.  Where the Confederacy was purely defensive, the Nazi state, like the party, was inherently extremely aggressive.

"We are U.S. citizens not because we asked for it. It was imposed by Congress just prior to the first world war. so our young Puerto Ricans then can go to the military service."
"So it's a duty of the United States to put their boots on the ground here in Puerto Rico. It's not like we are begging. It's what we deserve. We have been in every war, we have been fighting very hard, so now we deserve for them to be here."
"At the end of the day, two main things: He is talking to his electoral base. he is not talking law. He is showing that he is racist. Let's call it the right name."

Comment: I read your link the first time, it wasn't relevant to your point then either. Where does that link show us that revenue comes from academics, as you claimed? Where does it identify revenue sources at all (as my link did)? As I explained and cited, revenue comes from a lot of sources, primarily tuition, fees, and other sources that are collected per student. This revenue is then divided to different university departments, including both athletics and academics.

You seem stuck on the fact that NCAA football rarely "pays for itself:' i.e. doesn't bring in revenues that exceed expenses, and that in many cases student fees are used to make up the difference. Nobody really disputes this, but student fees are not, and never have been, dedicated solely to academics. Just because you don't value football doesn't mean people choosing universities can't value it. Also, most people understand that athletics don't have to be profitable in a vacuum to be beneficial for the university overall.

Comment: Ms. Wilson-Raybauld claims that Canadian views are based on denial because, among other things, "Indigenous peoples have to prove their rights in court even though they are recognized by section 35 of Canada’s Constitution". But this is hardly reason for complaint of any kind; the section in question only recognizes the existence of rights, it doesn't specify what those rights are. The only way therefore to determine the content of the rights in question is to claim them and then have that claim tested in court. Granted, we could have attempted to specify in the text of the Charter what those rights were, but I suspect that we would still be debating that matter today, more than 30 years later, if we had tried. Better to recognize the rights to begin with, then do the incremental work in the courts; that's a good thing, not a reason for saying that we're in denial.

Comment: "Ige’s main objection to the 2016 bill was that it would have allowed Airbnb, Inc. to collect taxes from the rentals it markets and remit them to the state without disclosing the identity of the unit owners. That would provide a “shield” for property owners who run illegal vacation rentals in communities where they are not allowed under city and county codes, he said."

Investors usually have a property manager. The best that Airbnb can do is identify the agent who is paying the tax. The exact address may not even be available. The state should figure out the ownership because they have all the records.

And even if the address is given in the ad, the agent may assign the unit after the payment is made. Which unit might depend on a schedule not set up on the website.

Probably the best solution is to just increase the get tax for vacation rentals. It's a vacation rental and not a hotel as the hotel industry has claimed.

Comment: Yes but we must also accept that there will be pain as a part of the normal aging process. it was big Pharma that started promoting about 2 decades ago that pain should be completely eliminated from people's lives. This is not realistic, and leads to the situation we have today. 

Pain should be managed and lived with using medications we already have until the condition becomes unbearable, which should only happen when a condition is inoperable.  Bone grinding on bone in a hip is unbearable. People need to get these surgeries faster. Nerve pain can be managed with other drugs, so can muscle pain, with physio, massage, chiropractic, yoga and staying active. (Physio, massage and Chiropractic are funded in BC by the way for low income people, and for insurance claims)

We cannot however expect that our lives will be lived with no pain. Feeling pain is a part of being alive, and it is a normal way for your body to complain about an injury and ask you to move and stretch and rest it.

Comment: The Heritage Fund wasn't "a lie" when it was established.  
https://thetyee.ca/Opinion/2011/04/13/HarpersBigQuestion/

Allan Warrack, one of the architects of the iconic Alberta Heritage Fund, told the Tyee [in 2011] that the province is being run [by PCs]  like a "banana republic" for failing to collect fair rents for non-renewable resources like the oil sands. 

"Since time immemorial, the use of other people's property has been on a two thirds, one third split," said Warrack. "The owner gets a third and the operator gets two thirds... If you interpret that in terms of oil or natural gas or oil sands, there should be a third of the value to the owners and in the case of oil sands that is 100 per cent owned by the public."

The royalty rate collected on oil sands projects before "payout" [in 2011] is one per cent, which according to Warrack is so low it is "like a rounding error from zero."

Comment: Wiki on the SPLC , and it is NOT a hate group...but folks involved in Hate Groups might see it that way.....:

In 1971, Morris Dees and Joseph J. Levin Jr. founded the SPLC as a civil rights law firm based in Montgomery, Alabama.[8] Civil rights leader Julian Bond joined Dees and Levin and served as president of the board between 1971 and 1979.[9]

The SPLC originally advocated for a broad range of progressive civil rights issues. In 1979 it began to fight the Ku Klux Klan and other white supremacist groups with an innovative litigating strategy involving filing civil suits for monetary damages on behalf of the victims of hate group harassment, threats, and violence. Given the decline in such groups over the years, the SPLC has become involved in other civil rights causes, including cases concerned with institutional racial segregation and discrimination, discrimination based on sexual orientation, the mistreatment of illegal immigrants, and the separation of church and state

Comment: I have registered many voters in my life, but never "unregistered one."  Each registration cancels the previous, as sworn to in the oath each registrar takes.  One can only be registered at his principal place of residence.  Since he can only have on of those, he can only be registered once.  It is the responsibility of the state to "unregister" someone.  Ballots should never be forwarded or mailed out-of-state (except for active-duty, military personnel).  If a person moves and fails to re-register, he may not vote at his old address, EXCEPT if he moved during the 32 days prior to an election.

Comment: Feb 29th 1504 was a good day for Christopher Columbus too. For several months the famous explorer had been marooned on the island of Jamaica. He had been greeted warmly by the natives who helped him and his vast ship and crew survive in the foreign land by providing food and guides etc. However his arrogance and disrespect for the people had caused them to stop this gesture of goodwill. Cause, you know, he was being a dick.

Outraged by this, Columbus consulted his shipboard almanac to ask if there was anything he could use to trick the natives. As it happens, there was a lunar eclipse coming up. On the 29th feb, the day of the eclipse, he gathered the natives and told them that god was angry for their disrespect and would take away the sun. Disappearing inside his ship during the eclipse, he waited as the good people begged for their women and children. He agreed to 'bring the sun back', and essentially enslaved the people until he was rescued.

WHAT A DICK.

Comment: You wrote "... such as lumber, metals/ores, natural gas, et cetera- that are in high demand world wide today, and that will, in future, only increase in their value to the province as exports..."

If lumber is in such high demand, why has the GDP contribution of forestry and lumber industry declined over 20% and mining, oil & gas declined by over 5%? Why did Ottawa just announce an almost $1 billion assistance program for the softwood lumber industry? Why is there still no LNG industry in BC? If you ask the mining industry they would say that the global demand for and prices of metals and ores has dropped off to the point where they are closing mines.

Comment: Regarding: "The order's leadership replied Tuesday that they are primarily recognized by the Vatican not as a religious order, but as a foreign state."
- Even the Knights and Dames are confused.
- Their recognition as an 'order' is primarily through the Holy See. The recognition of their sovereignty is via the Vatican City State.
- If they are an order then the Holy See can investigate them as such. When the 'order' and sovereignty overlap, the 'order' has precedence in  the investigation. This means 'sovereign' issues have no merit in the investigation.
- It is time for the Holy See and the Vatican City State to clearly differentiate themselves from each other so that that each does not conflict with the other as it does when the Holy See says treaties apply only to the Vatican City State, and the Vatican City State says what ever the Holy See decides is not the responsibility of the Vatican City State. By sorting this out the Knights and Dames will know where they stand in the world.

Comment: 2 Be --
Let me assure you -- you need not educate me about refugee resettlement.  I worked for several years with a resettlement agency.  Some of my clients are refugees who file for permanent residence.  I am intimately familiar with the process and the problems caused by the EO.  
Also, a federal judge recently ordered a stay on parts of that Order, and the 5th Circuit refused to lift that stay.  
Asylum is an immigration benefit.  I regularly work with people seeking asylum.  Many people who are considered by some to be coming for purely economic reasons are coming here because they fear some sort of persecution.  Unfortunately,  it's very hard to get asylum, so many people do not, although I think many of them should.  
People in detention centers can certainly file asylum claims.  The problem is that with a difficulty to access legal help, their asylum claims stand little chance.

Comment: Slightly more specifically the last year that net debt decrease in Ontario was during the 2001/02 fiscal year when the Premier was Mike Harris and the Finance Minister as Jim Flaherty.

Debt also decreased in 2000/01 under Harris and Ernie Eves as Finance Minister.  It also decreased in 1999/2000 though that year it only decreased because the proceeds of leasing the 407 ETR was booked during that year.  Without those proceeds the government would have been slightly deeper in debt at the end of the 1999/00 fiscal year.

So, excluding asset sales, we have a grand sum total of TWO years where the Ontario budget was truly "balanced" in the past 35+ years.

Comment: This is “an evolving situation” and we can delay acting pending greater clarity.  However, Canada must soon decide how it can comply with its international obligations respecting persons from the seven countries in question arriving here from the US.  It is unwelcome but true that the Safe Third Country Agreement is only consistent with Canada’s general obligations if the US is actually conducting legitimate adjudication of refugee claims and a pause or ban just doesn’t make the grade. 

A person arriving in Canada seeking refugee status, unlike an immigration applicant, has the right underv international conventions to protection either here or in some other country prepared to receive them. Canada can’t simply turn them away by relying upon a US blanket ban.

The suggestion that Canada will be inundated with applicants is misplaced and Canada can make special arrangements with the US and others for us to adjudicate the bulk of these claims before claimants arrive here.

Comment: I'm not sure whether taking the CV is an option or not.  We're Ontario Pension Board (98% funded as of 2015) for the DB and OPPA as our bargaining agent.  I like the idea of one of us taking the CV and the other the monthly cheque.  We'll have 7 years to figure it out.

Outliving the CV money is a combination of 2 things:  lifestyle and investment choices.

As for benefits (double dip).  We each will have benefits for life after 10 years of service.  I don'r believe we can opt out of it..unless you take a CV.  We're both finishing year 23 currently.  If the one with full pension & benefits dies first, the survivor benefits option kick in and the health, dental etc. are still in place as such.

Ironically, the older I get, the more this is about tax avoidance (not evasion).  I'm also looking at insurance use to pass money to the kids tax free as well.
I don't live in the GTA, so no million dollar houses etc. to worry about.

Comment: Brother Henry; I believe you answered your own question with your remark about RCC ( Rescue coordination Center)   who assigns the grids or paths and sometimes there is a high bird to relay that info or directions.   As you know, the aircraft fly sorties. ie a particular flight for a few hours before refueling or swapping out crews.  CAP planes from places like Homer and Kenai may well be assigned to arrive in an area after or before planes from Anchorage. If the search area has been narrowed down.   Air Force ( Alaska Air Guard 210th, 211th and 212th) planes will or can  be out there in low or no light looking for electric signals or possible heat sources.  During my 20 years in Public Safety, which overlapped 35 years with the CAP, we tried to keep our search grids separated enough to avoid a conflict.   The only problems I had as a search pilot were other folks blasting through the area at low level ( claiming they were helping) and twice with the AST helo getting into our grid.

Comment: “Single studies like this need to be interpreted with great caution. Risk does not mean an inevitable outcome. Furthermore, an association does not necessarily mean cause. An association may reflect a causal link between autism and severe depression or the association may reflect a causal link between the medication and autism.

The global evidence is increasingly showing that the risk of untreated depression or anxiety perinatally on the foetus and infant, are likely to outweigh the risks of antidepressants on offspring outcomes. Balancing the risks is an important part of the decision to treat with antidepressants or not. This decision needs to be individualized and made collaboratively, as part of the consultation between the woman and her practitioner.” Dr Simone Honikman, Perinatal Mental Health Project (PMHP)
